div.head: A DiÅ¿courÅ¿e made on the behalf of the Queen of England, in the Generall AÅ¿Å¿embly of the Clergy at Paris, concerning the preÅ¿ent Affaires of the Catholike, Religion in the Kingdom of England: By MonÅ¿ieur Jaques du Perron BiÅ¿hop of AngoleÅ¿me, Grand AlmoÅ¿ner to Her MajeÅ¿ty.
div.p:
IF the King of Great Britain be conÅ¿trained by the neceÅ¿Å¿ity and exigency of his Affaires, to come to an Accommodation with his Rebelled Subjects, as he will at laÅ¿t be inforced, and that in a very Å¿hort time, if He receive not Å¿peedy and effectuall Å¿uccors, That Accommodation will neceÅ¿Å¿arily bring with it, the totall deÅ¿truction of the Catholike Religion in that Kingdom. For as the firÅ¿t and principall Pretext, which the Parliamentarians Å¿erve themÅ¿elves off, to dreÅ¿Å¿e and colour over their Rebellion withall, and to Animate, Arme, and Unite all the Subjects together againÅ¿t their Lawfull Soveraign, hath been, to make them believe that he was a Catholike, and that he would introduce, and bring the Catholike Religion into that Kingdom; And as the firÅ¿t Article of all the Treaties that have been Å¿et on foot, and put forward by them hitherto, hath alwaies been, that of the Ruine and Extermination of the Catholikes; it is not to be doubted, they will never conclude any Accord or Agreement with their Prince, but upon that rigorous Condition, that the little CatholiciÅ¿me that yet remaines there, Å¿hould for ever be BaniÅ¿hed from thence, and that
all the Arms and Forces of England and Scotland Å¿hall be joyned together (as they have long Å¿ince reÅ¿olved amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves, and publiÅ¿hed in Print) to execute this unhappy and wicked deÅ¿ign plainly, that is to MaÅ¿Å¿acre and cut the throats of all the poor Catholikes, as they have already begun to do in divers places; And to drown and extinguiÅ¿h for ever in their blood, the Remainders and reliques of Religion, not only in England and Scotland, but alÅ¿o in Ireland, where they have been almoÅ¿t all preÅ¿erved in the Orthodox belief, notwithÅ¿tanding all the perÅ¿ecutions that have been raiÅ¿ed againÅ¿t them for theÅ¿e hundred years laÅ¿t paÅ¿t.

Now the deÅ¿truction of Monarchy in England, and the EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment of a Republike, and eÅ¿pecially of a Puritane Republike, which is the end that the Parliamentarians aime at, carrieth with it the greateÅ¿t prejudice that may be to the Catholike Religion: for the Extent of it will not be only in England, in Scotland, or in Ireland, but in all other parts of ChriÅ¿tendome. For if this Popular and Puritane State, Å¿hall once be formed in theÅ¿e three great Kingdoms, and after that Å¿hall Unite it Å¿elf with the Hereticks of Germany, Holland, and France, as is moÅ¿t agreeable to all Maximes of State, Religion, and IntereÅ¿t, and wch to effect, they are eÅ¿pecially concerned, and which is a deÅ¿ign, which the Parliamentarians had formed in their mindes from the inÅ¿tant of their Revolt, and of which they now Å¿pare not to make a clear and open profeÅ¿Å¿ion: All theÅ¿e powers thus United by the IntereÅ¿ts of State, and of Religion, the moÅ¿t Å¿trict and Å¿acred bonds of humane Å¿ociety, will render themÅ¿elves Å¿o formidable to all the reÅ¿t of ChriÅ¿tendome, as they will be able in Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of time (if God Å¿hall not mightily interpoÅ¿e his hand) to undermine, and utterly to ruine all the Catholikes. And this is that which the Parliamentarians hope to come unto at laÅ¿t, when they Å¿hall have rooted up Monarchy from among themÅ¿elves, for they hate the Church, yet more then they hate Royalty. And is it not to be feared, that if the Catholikes of other Countreys, Å¿hall Å¿hew themÅ¿elves Å¿o little Å¿enÅ¿ible of the ruine of Religion in England, and Å¿hall not be ready to give their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance for the maintenance and preÅ¿ervation of the Å¿ame, that God by his juÅ¿t judgement Å¿hould permit that themÅ¿elves Å¿hould fall into the Å¿ame unhappineÅ¿Å¿e and miÅ¿ery of SchiÅ¿me and HereÅ¿ie, from which they have had no heart to preÅ¿erve and defend their brethren, and their neighbors? And is it
not to be feared that God to puniÅ¿h our regardleÅ¿nes, & looÅ¿enes in the things of his Å¿ervice, and of his glory, and our little zeal for the Augmentation, and ConÅ¿ervation of the Catholike Religion, Å¿hould permit the Å¿ame Catholike Religion to be wholly ruined, and rooted out of the reÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Countreys, in which it yet continueth in Europe, as in the Ages paÅ¿t, to chaÅ¿tiÅ¿e the Å¿ins of thoÅ¿e that lived before us, he hath permitted that it Å¿hould be wholly deÅ¿troyed, in all AÅ¿ia, Affrick, and the greateÅ¿t part of Europe it Å¿elfe, and to tranÅ¿plant it wholly into America, and that new world, which were the greateÅ¿t unhappineÅ¿Å¿e that could befall us; and which we ought to endeavour to hinder by all the meanes we can, all the dayes of our lives?

The King of England hath promiÅ¿ed by a Letter which he hath written to the Queen his Å¿pouÅ¿e, to revoke and repeal all thoÅ¿e Laws which have at any time been made againÅ¿t the Catholikes in England, in caÅ¿e he can receive from the Catholikes any aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, to put him into a Condition of power and Authority to be able to do it. There is now no danger to declare this promiÅ¿e, which hath been kept Å¿ecret hitherto: for that the Parliamentarians having Å¿urpriÅ¿ed the Copie of the Å¿aid Letter, have Printed and publiÅ¿hed the Å¿ame, to render the King the moÅ¿t odious to the People that they can; & to render the Catholikes the moÅ¿t Å¿uÅ¿pects. And were not this now the greateÅ¿t good that could poÅ¿Å¿ible come to the Catholike Religion? For were not this to give and eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h in a Å¿ort, the liberty of Catholike Religion in England? which if it were once eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed there, it is moÅ¿t certain that we Å¿hould Å¿hortly Å¿ee the greateÅ¿t part of that Countrey re-united to the Church: for there are now already a fourth part, yea, even near a third part, who are Catholikes, either Å¿ecret or open; There is one other third part, who are held in SchiÅ¿m, only from the apprehenÅ¿ion of temporall puniÅ¿hment, and the loÅ¿Å¿e of their goods, and by the fear of the Laws, which being once revoked, as the King of England promiÅ¿eth now they Å¿hall, in caÅ¿e he can be aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted, they would alÅ¿o preÅ¿ently embrace the Catholike faith. And who can tell whether the divine providence hath not permitted that the King of England Å¿hould fall into thoÅ¿e difficulties, and extremities, into which he is now reduced, to the end, that being preÅ¿Å¿ed by the neceÅ¿Å¿ity and exigency of his Affaires, he might take this good reÅ¿olution, which God no doubt hath inÅ¿pired him with
for the advantage of his Church? And who knowes whether when this King hath been Å¿o Å¿eaÅ¿onably and Å¿enÅ¿ibly engaged and obliged by the Catholikes, God may not take that occaÅ¿ion to touch his heart, and open his eyes to the light of the faith?

The Å¿econd conÅ¿ideration, which ought to carry you more effectually, and particularly to this aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance beyond the reÅ¿t of the Church, is your particular intereÅ¿t, that is to Å¿ay, the danger in which you are, in regard of your vicinity to England, as being neerer then any other Catholike kingdome; Å¿o as when HereÅ¿ie Å¿hall have ruined Religion in England, it may with greateÅ¿t Å¿peed, paÅ¿Å¿e over to deÅ¿troy it alÅ¿o in France.

Res tua tunc agitur, paries cum proximus ardet. For we know of certain knowledge, that this is the deÅ¿igne and Å¿cope of the Parliamentarians; and that this is all the hope and the only refuge of the Huguenots; upon this hope it is, that they travell with Å¿o great diligence and vehemency, to help forward, and to publiÅ¿h the advantages of the Parliamentarians; 'Tis upon this hope they Contribute Å¿o great Å¿ums That the Reader be not miÅ¿taken in this particular, he is to take notice, that the Orator uÅ¿eth this as an Argument, to provoke the French Clergy to a full contribution to the Queen in Emulation of the Huguenots; wherein he impoÅ¿eth upon them, there never having been Å¿o much as one peny ever leavied by them, or Å¿ent into England, for the uÅ¿e of the Parliament. which they leavy upon themÅ¿elves, and Å¿ecretly convey into England. And truly this their hope perhaps is not Å¿o vaine nor ill grounded, as Å¿ome may be ready to imagine: for if the Huguenots at their firÅ¿t birth, and when they began to appear in this Kingdome, being only upheld by the protection of Å¿ome petty Hereticall Princes of Germany, made themÅ¿elves in Å¿hort time Å¿o conÅ¿iderable, as they were able to Å¿et on foot at divers times Å¿uch Prodigious Armies, to give an hundred and an hundred encounters with our forces, to gaine many Å¿ignall Victories, to take a great number of the beÅ¿t Townes of this Kingdome, to keep whole Provinces intire, and to ruine and deÅ¿troy wherever they came the Catholike Religion, of which we Å¿ee yet, the lamentable marks and Å¿cars in all parts of this Kingdome, but principally in the DioceÅ¿es of Guienne and Languedoc; what will it be, when beÅ¿ide the Å¿uccours of the Hereticks of Germany (who are now incomparably more powerfull then they were in thoÅ¿e times,) they Å¿hall be aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted by the Puritanes of England, Scotland and Ireland, united in one body of a Republike, the moÅ¿t formidable of all ChriÅ¿tendome? certainly it muÅ¿t be
avowed, that all thoÅ¿e evils with which they have afflicted the Church of France in the times paÅ¿t, are nothing, in comparriÅ¿on of thoÅ¿e with which we are threatned for the future. The truth is, the Huguenots have been very much weakened, but they have not been yet intirely rooted out, they are yet in as great number, and have as great animoÅ¿ity againÅ¿t us as ever; we have taken indeed from them their Towns, and Å¿trong places, but their hatred toward us remains, and their deÅ¿ire of Revenge Å¿till lives, and they attend but for an occaÅ¿ion to make the Å¿ame appear, which can never be preÅ¿ented to them more favorably, then by the eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment of a Puritane Republike in England; and therefore, if this Å¿hall ever come to paÅ¿Å¿e, as without all doubt it will come to paÅ¿Å¿e one day, if it be not preÅ¿ently and effectually hindred, we Å¿hall Å¿ee again in France, the Churches ruined, Sepulchres profaned, the aÅ¿hes of the dead caÅ¿t into the wind, as they have done even to Å¿ome of our Kings and others. Behold, this is that which the Huguenots of France promiÅ¿e us, this is that which the Parliamentarians of England prepare for us, in caÅ¿e they can finiÅ¿h their work with their King and their Queen. Shall it be Å¿aid to poÅ¿terity? Shall it be Å¿aid to the Å¿hame of Catholikes, and particularly to the oprobry of the Clergy of France, that the Huguenots of France contributed Å¿o joyfully and freely, great Å¿ums for the aid of the Parliamentarians, that is to Å¿ay, for the enemies of God, of the holy. Church his Å¿pouÅ¿e, of your dignities and Å¿acred Character? Å¿hall it be Å¿aid that they have made great Collections to Å¿end into England, to help to deÅ¿troy, and root up from the foundation the Kingdom of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, and to advance yet further, and Å¿et up there the Kingdome of Satan; hoping when that Å¿hall be effected to their mindes, to do the Å¿ame thing here in France: and that the Catholikes, and eÅ¿pecially the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticks, who live only upon the Patrimony of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, and who have proteÅ¿ted in their Ordination in the face and preÅ¿ence of the whole Church, that they would renounce all the periÅ¿hable poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions of this world, and to have none other Inheritance then the Lord, no other PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion then IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, (Dominus pars haereditatis meae & calicis mei) Å¿hould not a little retrench and abridge themÅ¿elves in Å¿ome Å¿mall thing, whereby to help and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the Å¿etting up of the Kingdome of the Å¿ame Lord and the Å¿ame IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t in England, and to preÅ¿erve to him the Inheritance which he hath there purchaÅ¿ed to himÅ¿elf, at the
Price of his owne moÅ¿t pretious blood, and with that of Å¿o many Martyrs, and by conÅ¿equence inevitable, to preÅ¿erve unto him here in France that kingdome, which he hath here poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed for theÅ¿e Å¿ixteen hundred years?

I conclude this diÅ¿courÅ¿e with one conÅ¿ideration, which reÅ¿pects you yet more particularly then the reÅ¿t of the Church, in regard of the quality you bear as French. A ConÅ¿ideration nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e which the Queen of England hath even commanded me to Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e, conceiving the IntereÅ¿t of her own perÅ¿on, and that of her children, of Å¿o Å¿mall conÅ¿ideration, as Å¿he dares not mingle them with the IntereÅ¿ts of Religion. NotwithÅ¿tanding it Å¿eemed to me, that I could not omit it without breach of Piety and good Nature that is, to conÅ¿ider a little the eminent perill and danger, wherein the Queen of England and her children now are, to fall into a more deplorable and miÅ¿erable condition then ever perÅ¿ons of their birth and quality were reduced unto: to Å¿ee on the one Å¿ide Å¿ix young Princes and PrinceÅ¿Å¿es, the tendernes of whoÅ¿e age, is yet within the verge & Limit of Innocence; Princes, which are the grand-children, Nephews, and CouÅ¿in Germans of our Kings; Princes, who derive their birth and blood from twenty or two and twenty Kings of England, and from twelve or fifteen Kings of Scotland, and who are generally allyed to all the Crowned heads of ChriÅ¿tendome, and of whom for that cauÅ¿e, it may as juÅ¿tly be Å¿aid, as of the children of the Emperors of ConÅ¿tantinople of old, that they were ingendred of Purple,
Cum MajeÅ¿tate creatos,
Nulla
que privatae paÅ¿Å¿os contagia Å¿ortis.
Born in the glory and midÅ¿t of the Å¿plendor of Soveraign MajeÅ¿ty; nouriÅ¿hed and brought up upon the Royall Throne, in hopes to command one day great and powerfull Nations: To Å¿ee them I Å¿ay now at the very point of being deÅ¿poyled of three great Kingdomes, which Å¿o many of their AnceÅ¿tors have left them from hand to hand, as a well-aÅ¿Å¿ured patrimony; to be conÅ¿trained to leave their native Countrey now in their tender Age, and to wander in Å¿trange countreys as vagabonds to Å¿eek the Å¿ecurity of their lives and perÅ¿ons, and even there to eat that bread, which they cannot eat in their own houÅ¿e, and amongÅ¿t their own Subjects and Citizens, is a thing, that none who hath ought of the tenderneÅ¿Å¿e of a man left in him can Å¿peak or think of without teares.

div.p:
Was the Å¿aying of a deÅ¿poyled Prince in the Tragick Poet; to Å¿ee on the other Å¿ide a moÅ¿t Catholike PrinceÅ¿Å¿e, whoÅ¿e veines contein and hold, and in which there runs along the pretious blood of our St. Lewis, which is not only the life of her body, but alÅ¿o animates, and impregnates her heart with the Å¿ame Å¿entments of Piety, which hath acquired to that great Saint a Crown of Glory in the Heavens, & a Å¿hrine in our Temples; A PrinceÅ¿s, who in imitation of that moÅ¿t imitable Saint, hath Å¿et up the Altars, and the true worÅ¿hip of God in England, and hath cauÅ¿ed the Catholike Religion again to grow and triumph there, with all the Å¿plendor and glory imaginable, for the Å¿pace of 15 or 16 years, in deÅ¿pite of all the oppoÅ¿ition that HereÅ¿ie could make againÅ¿t it, and that after it had been continually oppreÅ¿Å¿ed and perÅ¿ecuted for the Å¿pace of an hundred years: yea, Å¿o far had this proceeded, as there hath been even in the chief City of the Kingdome, a Covent of Capuchin Fathers, Preaching, CatechiÅ¿ing, and ConfeÅ¿Å¿ing every day publikely, and that not only in French, but alÅ¿o in EngliÅ¿h, adminiÅ¿tring the Sacraments, & Celebrating divine Å¿ervice wth as much Å¿olemnity and liberty, & I durÅ¿t even Å¿ay in proportion, with as great affluence of people, as in any Church in Paris, The King Å¿aying nothing to it, nor any of the MiniÅ¿ters of State, or JuÅ¿tice of that Kingdome daring to impeach or hinder it, eÅ¿pecially for theÅ¿e laÅ¿t ten years; yea, even Å¿o far, that there hath been Å¿een to the Admiration of all ChriÅ¿tendome, that which hath not been Å¿een Å¿ince the time of the SchiÅ¿me, and that which none could have dared ever to hope to Å¿ee again, namely, ReÅ¿idents from the Court of England at Rome, to Treat there with the Pope of the affaires of Religion, and Reciprocally three Nuntio's from the Pope in the Court of England, namely, the Seigniours, Gregory Panzani, BiÅ¿hop of Mileto in Italy, Georgio Coneo, a ScottiÅ¿h man by Nation, but a DomeÅ¿tick of the laÅ¿t Pope, and of the Cardinall Barbarini, and Seignior RoÅ¿Å¿etti, who was made Cardinall at his going out of England, all theÅ¿e Negotiating in the Å¿aid Court, during the Å¿pace of Å¿even or eight years, with as much liberty, yea, even familiarity, as in the Court of any other Catholike Prince whatÅ¿oever: and all this by the conduct, zeale, and credit of the Queen of England, who by theÅ¿e Å¿weet Å¿teps walked fairely on toward the ConverÅ¿ion of that Kingdome, and which it Å¿eemed, we might Å¿peedily have hoped for,
after Å¿o happy and proÅ¿perous beginnings (but our Å¿ins have turned away that unexpected happineÅ¿Å¿e) a PrinceÅ¿Å¿e, who hath given a confidence to the poor EngliÅ¿h Catholikes, to come forth from their retirements, where they remained Å¿hut up in obÅ¿curity, and to appear in the light with their faces erected, to profeÅ¿Å¿e and exerciÅ¿e their Religion with all aÅ¿Å¿urance; to aÅ¿pire after, and actually obtain Offices and Charges in the Court and State, after they had been for the Å¿pace of an age without liberty of breathing, or rather Å¿ighing in Å¿ecret; a PrinceÅ¿s, who by her Alms, or rather by her immenÅ¿e Liberalities (of which I can give TeÅ¿timonie, for that the moÅ¿t part thereof paÅ¿Å¿ed through my hands,) hath reÅ¿tored life to many intire families, (yea, even of the moÅ¿t Noble of England) who had been deÅ¿poyled of all their EÅ¿tates for the cauÅ¿e of Religion, & who were upon the point to die by a cruell and lingring famine;
